pullRequest.body:
This resolves the Zulip comment [here](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Bounds.20on.20alternating.20convergent.20series/near/416938975).

---

This looks good to me now, and I'll exercise my newly obtained powers to maintainer merge :smile:
This looks good to me now, and I'll exercise my newly obtained powers to maintainer merge :smile:

This should be easier using [CauchySeq.comp_tendsto](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/UniformSpace/Cauchy.html#CauchySeq.comp_tendsto).

Anyway, I would assume that it should be possible to modify the previous proof to give the result directly (but I didn't check myself).

Maybe not...

To go via [CauchySeq.comp_tendsto](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/UniformSpace/Cauchy.html#CauchySeq.comp_tendsto), one would need a congruence lemma that says that when two sequences agree eventually, one is Cauchy iff the other one is. But I can't find this in Mathlib.
(The problem is that `n - 1 + 1 = n` does not hold for all `n`.)

So I would suggest that you add a general statement
```lean
lemma CauchySeq.shift {Î± : Type*} [UniformSpace Î±] (u : â„• â†’ Î±) (k : â„•) :
    CauchySeq (fun n â†¦ u (n + k)) â†” CauchySeq u := ...
```
say in `Mathlib.Topology.UniformSpace.Cauchy` and use that in the proof.
Done.

```suggestion
    intro a ha b hb
    convert h (a - k) (Nat.le_sub_of_add_le ha) (b - k) (Nat.le_sub_of_add_le hb) <;> omega
```
`omega` is a bit overkill for the first two side goals.
Done.
Could you exchange the two sides of the iff? A general rule of thumb is that the more complicated expression should be on the left of the iff.
Done.
